review_title: A great place to work & make a difference!
job_title: Medical Practice Manager in Rockford, IL
pros: I have been with Rosecrance for over five years and have been afforded excellent opportunities for growth. I feel that my hard work & work ethic is acknowledged and appreciated. I feel empowered to bring about positive change and this is such an important thing. Each supervisor I’ve reported to over the past several years has consistently taken the time to acknowledge the value I bring to the company and respects my thoughts and opinions. As a Registered Nurse, I feel supported as a member of the nursing team and Rosecrance does a great job of consistently working to improve working conditions and work-life balance for nursing staff. Even on my most challenging days, I’m left feeling certain that I have made a difference for others that day, whether that be for our clients or my peers. I am so proud of the work Rosecrance does and feel blessed to be a part of it.
cons: The field of behavioral health is a challenging field, made even more so by the impact of Covid. It can be emotionally draining at times, as it’s impossible to not be affected by some of our client’s struggles with their mental illness or addiction. This is not unique to Rosecrance though.

pros: I love how rewarding the job is
cons: No one communicates at all

pros: Rosecrance strengthened my spine and gave me the opportunity to work on standing up for myself and the program I worked in. The clients are what kept me working there for so long. I wanted to quit for years but the question of who will take care of them when I’m gone always remained in my mind. I developed a thicker skin and resiliency while working here.
cons: Where to even begin… - The productivity expectations are incredibly unreasonable. It’s never taken into consideration when you are out sick, are given supervisory responsibilities, and have no one to put on the schedule. I understood the reason for productivity but there was always such a focus on the numbers and never a focus on what can be done to improve the numbers. There was never a solution focused conversation; you’re just told to be better. - There are no opportunities for work/life balance. You will be asked to give your life to Rosecrance. If you’re burned out? No one cares. You’ll ask for help and you’ll never get it. Administration and HR will literally laugh in your face when you bring concerns to them. There’s always conversations and training on “self care” but you never have the opportunity to use PTO to actually work on self care. If you do, you’ll get in trouble for not reaching your productivity standard. The pay out was nice when I left due to having so many hours of unusable PTO. - The turnover might very well be the highest I’ve ever seen before. - There’s never any real problem solving going on. There will be meetings to talk about the problems but that’s where it ends. There’s never any follow through or actions to address the issues.

pros: Positive experience with coworkers, that’s about it.
cons: - minimal pay with either no raises or 2 cent raise - demanding on call schedule. it was not listed within my job description that I would be on call, as I wouldn’t have accepted a position with that responsibility. As a student who was also working full time, I was being woken up several times throughout the night. - poor communication with management. I was managed remotely by my supervisor from a different location, and I was more or less out of the loop on anything and everything. - asking for help or clarification was out of the question - after inquiring about a program at a facility I didn’t work at, I was informed to “manage my own case” by a higher up. - favoritism among higher ups and HR regarding who could work remotely for what reason. I was informed WFH was temporary only for those with FMLA or other illness related issues. However, several people I knew worked from home indefinitely. When my car broke down, I was forced to come into the office and more or less threatened with being written up.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Crystal Lake, IL
pros: Rosecrance offers fair pay to their employees. Plenty of PTO.
cons: Terrible leadership team. There were many inappropriate male staff and their actions seemed to be encouraged instead of reprimanded. Higher management held everyone to an unrealistic standard. It’s unfair that some staff were allowed to work from home but others were required to go in no matter the circumstance. Staff came and went as they pleased as long as they were liked by management. It was impossible to reach the director the majority of the time. There was no regard for staffs safety. People would be threatened and it was not taken seriously until the director felt like they were being threatened. Holidays are not given off, you must use your own PTO to be off even if the office is closed. This isn’t mentioned during the interview process nor orientation. It’s a revolving door.

pros: Compensation, ongoing education, career path, promotes within, willing to look at all sides of issues in order to resolve them, continuing to evolve and grow.
cons: Some processes not in place, which might be expected to be of an organization with a robust history. Staff and management are proactively working on defining, refining, and improving processes as the organization continues to grow.

review_title: Okay place to start if you like consistent stress
job_title: Mental Health Clinician in McHenry, IL
pros: Pay is okay for nonprofit. Telehealth is allowed.
cons: Hours, pay does not match the amount of work, human resources is completely separate from Rosecrance Health making employees feel neglected and disengaged, most management is disconnected from the mental health piece and makes productivity top priority while encouraging and enforcing numbers of clients to be therapists’ main goal over advocacy and compassion for clients. Clinical supervision is limited, it took almost a year to start supervision. Benefits suck. You are required to use your pto for holidays, which they omit from the interview. Healthcare packages are not that great and do not offer HMO.

pros: Really great place to gain experience in the fields of psychology/social work. Freedom to create programming and contribute ideas. Lots of interaction with terrific clients. Responding to relapses and mental health crises is challenging but you learn a lot. Fun to work as a team! Positive upbeat environment.
cons: Treatment focuses too narrowly on surface level cognitive behavioral approaches, so too many clients relapse and die. This place is part of a larger societal treatment system that in many ways does not help clients and families address the root cause—the emotional pain, childhood trauma, and dysfunctional family patterns underlying clients’ addictive behavior.

pros: Coworkers and clients are great!
cons: Upper management has no idea how to be leaders. They are not supportive and the company proved time and time again that they don’t care about their employees

pros: Help with addiction and mental illness. Non-discriminatory. Great employees
cons: The pay scale is too low and the workload is very busy.

review_title: Not a good company-only cares about bottom line-$
pros: -Experience -Nice office/facility -Great trainings -Decent pay -Benefits are okay
cons: -Management/HR not great -Co-workers-bullying -Favoritism -Expect you to take clients to places -Clients can treat you however they feel like

pros: Helped me to develop resiliency
cons: Poor management, lack of professionalism, no support and low pay

pros: The clients and population you work with.
cons: Management, HR, pay increase, communication, training, supervisors

pros: My coworkers were amazing and supportive.
cons: Difficult work environment with overly high expectations.

pros: I was able to familiarize myself with the area as it is a community based job.
cons: Poor management style. I had 2 supervisors that communicated poorly with one another. I was micromanaged into a state of depression and quit so keep my mental health intact.

review_title: Rosecrance KILLED everything good about Jackson Recovery
job_title: Medical Billing Specialist in Sioux City, IA
pros:
I worked in the billing department from 2016 through End of 2019. While the pay was never very good, I was hired when Iowa Medicaid outsourced to 3 major insurance companies. Claims were rejected and unpaid for years. They did away with End of Year Bonuses that year, and they never returned. My promised pay increase after 90 days was not honored, nor did I EVER receive more than a standard 3% pay increase (nothing for first 2 years). Bachelor degree, student loans, and making $15 an hour with no cost of living adjustments, and rising benefit premiums… it was not sustainable to make so little, while everything gets more expensive. 

Having said that- I really loved working for Jackson Recovery prior to the Rosecrance merger. I loved my job, and I took pride in it. I made a lot of personal sacrifices to stay, hoping to merit a large raise, and move into management. That all went away by June of 2019 with the merger.
cons:
Really Bad Pay!!
No Student Loan repayment Program
Long difficult hours, no flexibility, terrible management
Where did all the Bullies come from! 

Rosecrance was promoted as being a great opportunity for current employees. It became clear very quickly that the patients didn’t matter, just the bills Lea. My job description no longer fulfilled me. I was a glorified data entry clerk, no longer using my skills and in any way. Any hope for advancement disappeared immediately, as did any opportunity to stand out. 

Gossip and bullying became prevalent among all staff, as did back stabbing. The culture became TOXIC, and anyone of value quickly left for greener pastures . Mandatory “fun” paid for by employees ($5.00 is a lot to ask when you pay skilled educated employees less than entry level production workers) was a laughable attempt to promote team building. 
Employee programs that existed to help employees in times of hardship (death of immediate family member) were quickly erased. Everything that made Jackson stand out as a caring employer vanished. 
2.5 years later, I make almost double what They paid, have fun and kind coworkers, and am much happier than I was at Rosecranse. It’s sad really how bad things have gotten. Rosecrance poisons every company they take over.

pros: There are a lot of opportunities to learn here.
cons: Higher ups need to listen to staff more.

review_title: Great coworkers and job experience, poor upper management
pros: Great, passionate and competent coworkers, okay starting pay, great on-the-job experience
cons:
-Upper management is greedy and only cares about maximizing billing
-Upper management is out of touch with actual employee needs
-Using PTO is pretty much a lose-lose because you put yourself behind schedule and have to make up the work when you go back in, upper management does not adjust for PTO when counting your billable hours.
-Work-life balance is difficult but manageable if you're passionate about the job

pros: Supportive coworkers . . .
cons:
Low pay/ minimum raises
burnout of current staff due to large amount of stars quitting

pros: Rosecrance is by far the best place I've ever worked. Everyone is extremely kind and welcoming; the CEO, Dr. Gomel, is super involved and down to earth; the mission is impactful; and it's one of those rare companies where it's obvious just how much people care. There are so many opportunities for inclusivity, diversity, and learning, which go to show how genuine this organization is. Suggestions for change are always listened to and even encouraged by the executives. This is a company where you feel you are actually making a difference.
cons: If you are not on the clinical side of Rosecrance, opportunities for growth are a bit hard to come by. Also, Rosecrance is a not-for-profit organization, so salaries are not outstanding.

review_title: Only a stepping stone job, not a career
pros:
The people who work there are great and passionate.
Lower level management is pretty personable.
Can be a rewarding job.
Has several “employees appreciation “ events, walks and cookouts.
cons:
HR does not appreciate longevity and seniority is not a term used there. The company almost discouraged more than 5-7 years experience with them. After that, the only benefit you have over a new person is your merrit increases, but they find a way to erase them too (such as “across the board raises” that exclude employees who have been there longer - they will say they are happy with what they are already paying you), thus, giving you a pay decrease and punishing you for working there longer than others. This causes the company to be severely understaffed, sometimes having to close units or buildings in order to keep running. In turn, that leaves the people who stay with them more stressed and working harder while earning less and less when faced with inflation. Then more people quit and it becomes a viscous cycle.
Can also be a very emotionally taxing job also.

review_title: JOIN THE TEAM OF MISERABLE PEOPLE!
job_title: CD Counselor in Sioux City, IA
pros: Patients are worth it.But all are court ordered.
cons: Too much, with too little time.Numbers are more important than care.

pros: Great teamwork and collaboration. Staff truly care about patients
cons: The workload is dangerous for staff and patients. They understaff on purpose which causes high burnout and turn over

pros: The night supervisor is nice.
cons: Most of the people who work there day in and day out are doing the bare minimum. Work place culture is weak.

pros: Absolutely nothing at all! Sorry
cons:
Complete Trash. They treat you like trash, walk on you like trash and if you don't hit production you will be thrown away like trash. 
Very trashy place.

pros: I had an amazing supervisor and awesome coworkers
cons: Low pay for large amount of work. Not caring for employees mental and physical health. Paying people different wages for the same job. Extremely low pay for comparable jobs. Focused more on how much money they could make by taking on as many clients as they can and forcing group work as they make more money on groups than individual sessions.

job_title: Medical Assistant in Machesney Park, IL
pros: Good people. Great bosses, great hours, fair pay
cons: Away from taking son to and from school,

review_title: Poor management support, unprofessional, and somewhat unethical
pros: Coworkers, clients, decent pay, PTO
cons: Management, lack of transparency, overworked, lack of support, role confusion

pros:
I am finally on a team where everyone's role helps complete the common goal and everyone works together as a team to support each other's individual goals.
The management team has done an excellent job in reinvesting in staff!
cons: Sometimes making sure everyone that needs to be communicating during a project from all of the different business areas allows details to be overlooked. Thankfully, management is working on how to increase communication across the different teams!

pros: Team, trainings, time off, ability of overtime.
cons: Salary increases, lack of advancement

job_title: Primary Counselor%2C Substance Abuse in Rockford, IL
pros: Co-workers , starter job for college graduates
cons: Dangerously understaffed, poor pay for the amount of work, constant turnover at every level

pros: There is a sense of community
cons: Health insurance benefits could be better

pros: hard to think of anything. really dont seem to care about employees. below industry standards but its a paycheck
cons: lot of turnover with high level leadership positions, management is unstable. everything changes for the worse once youre hired. pretty grim place

pros: Clients are great. Good benefits
cons: Leadership. Not paid properly for overtime

job_title: Access Counselor in Crystal Lake, IL
pros: Great place to learn. Good co workers. Clients are challenging but rewarding. Direct supervisors do the best they can to support frontline staff.
cons: Employees are expendable. Productivity is more important than morale. Turnover is high. Training is poor. Overall, the company is unwilling demonstrate how they value long term, licensed employees.

job_title: Human Resources Assistant in Rockford, IL
pros: Nothing! If you have kids, they don't care about family!
cons: This place promotes mental health care but employees are made to put the company first. Just stay away! They work you to death then disregard you!!!

pros: It is a good place to work
cons: It has good opportunities within

pros: Free meals and decent insurance
cons: Understaffed, underpayed, high work load.

pros: Collegial atmosphere with experienced team
cons: Understaffed and stays that way

pros: Working with the children was such a rewarding experience.
cons: Low pay compared to workload. No work/life balance. Transphobic/homophobic company. Unethical practices and will do anything to make a dollar.

pros: you learn a lot about the mental health industry and network with a lot of key players
cons: stressful as management has unrealistic expectations for lower staff and does not have much knowledge to help out with problems when they arise. undervalued and over worked.

pros: Hire great coworkers, good benefits
cons: Terrible leadership, terrible pay, high workload, high expectations. Toxic culture - higher management will talk about employees. They lost their mission years ago. They bring in new management to sweep out staff and ignore when said management gets arrested.

job_title: Mental Health Counselor in Champaign, IL
pros: Reasonable pay, health, dental and eye insurance.
cons:
The volume of work is unreasonable. Counselors are salary. You will never work 40 hours a week. You will work 50+. The administration in Rockford makes questionable decisions for the Central Illinois locations. It is clear that money is more important than quality of care. 

No paid holidays. You must use PTO if you want paid for a holiday. I would never recommend anyone working here.

pros: It’s a full time job
cons: The benefits are not great

review_title: Great place to work and gain experience in the social service field.
pros: Great coworkers, Great teamwork, Love the administration!
cons: Need better compensation for what is expected.

pros: Supportive management staff and supervisors
cons: Typically low staffed and higher turnover rates

pros: Good Goood Goooood GOOOOOD GOOOOD
cons: Fine it was fine like just fine

review_title: It’s great as a first stepping stone....
pros:
Friendly environment
Great entry level experience
cons:
Little opportunity for growth
Poor upper management
Client care sometimes takes a back seat

job_title: Performance Improvement Specialist in Rockford, IL
pros: They paid for employee's benefits, at least when I was there.  I left in 2002
cons: Everything.  Very political.  Had some incidents with the CEO where they were trying to blame the "black client" that was in the office for theft.  They didn't stop to think that it could have been anyone.  Lack of training for position.  I pretty much had to train myself in my job.  My supervisor gave me a low rating for teamwork because I was in a location that was not with my team.  Like that is my fault!!! I will never forget that unfair remark.  For that, I only got a 1% raise and never received the other 2% as promised.  I hated working at the adult facility.  I wished they would have kept me at the adolescent facility. Too many clicks and butt kissing at the adult facility.  My boss moved me to be with my team and I disliked it.  I did my work and stayed in my office.  She told me that I should mingle and make friends.  When I did, she told me that I get paid by the hour when I tried to "mingle".  She couldn't make up her mind!

pros: co-workers, health insurance, 401 K, clients, dental, vision
cons: poor leadership, no support, toxic work culture, over-worked,

pros: Co workers, working with clients and PTO
cons: Pay, lacking support from leadership, staffing

pros: Working for an organization with the resources and talent to address substance abuse, behavioral health and co-occurring disorders is a wonderful way to give back to the community.  It is extremely busy and runs with as lean an organization as possible but there are tremendous rewards.  Rosecrance facilities and properties are top-notch and the organization is growing both in its geographical areas of service and in client population.  With this comes a slower rate of staff growth, but there is staff growth to meet the ever-growing demand.  The work is challenging and varied, and opportunities for professional training and growth exist.  The culture tries to keep overtime demands as low as possible, but there is overtime and it is managed.  Benefits are good and HR works hard at keeping the employee contribution portion as low as possible.
cons: Being a non-profit, salaries are lower than anyone would like.  Some of these pay issues really need to be addressed because the attrition low pay causes hurts the organization and it mission.

review_title: Values money more than the agency's mission.
pros: Clients, coworkers. Services the agency provides is great and has dedicated people. Staff truly care about the work they are doing and only stick around as long as they do because of the clients. But everyone has a breaking point. Training department was fantastic and actually something I miss at my new job. Very organized and helpful and ensured credentials were maintained.
cons: Unrealistic expectations of time management to manage extremely high case loads, money hungry, doesn't value employees, benefits only look good on paper, horrible HR department, management encouraged to give employees low scores on evaluations to avoid full raise, doesn't know how to boost morale, negative attitude from HR/management, doesn't value front line staff and sees them as warm bodies to generate billable services (which equals money). Wastes money on keeping up appearances.

pros: Amazing and dedicated coworkers.  Powerful mission that motivates.  Benefit packages are wonderful, especially for a long term employee.  Well kept facilities.
cons: Top heavy in regards to executive leadership pay vs the salary range for direct care and lower management positions.  Significant disparity between what is marketed as best practices and what is actually practiced in treatment settings.  Best practices are compromised for financial gain.   Cliques and politics are webbed into the dysfunctional culture.  If you are not with the “it” crowd, then you are not good enough no matter what your bring to the team.

review_title: Success Based on Productivity NOT Recovery
pros: Great co-workers. Great clients.  Good benefits,. You will love this company if staff  turnover, huge workloads, and little to no job training are your idea of insuring your job stability and career opportunities. The middle managers try, but are mouthpieces for executive leadership who may have stated, out loud they are, "not so good with people relationships or empathy."
cons: Staff often speak in whispers. But worst of all, the workload and often the computer system  makes your job difficult every day to be competent in supporting client recovery causing compassion fatigue. Management treats compassion fatigue with lip service by ignoring the cure: manageable work loads.

pros: Benefits, competitive pay, training opportunities (CEUs)
cons: No awareness of staff being overworked/burnt out. Lack of training to complete job duties, favoritism is often shown, no or little chance of advancement if you are not the favorite. Supervisors (not all but some) can be a little malicious and not trusted. Also, there is ALOT of pettiness, laziness amongst the staff if one doesn't want to do it, it can be passed to the next. Lastly, just because you are hired for one position doesn't mean that it will be the only thing you do, this is when you become burnt out

job_title: Mental Health Therapist in Rockford, IL
pros: Great coworkers and direct supervisor is great.
cons: The company’s priority is making money which causes a high stress, high pressure, low moral work environment. Meeting productivity is primarily what they talk about and how they make decisions on the care they provide. That causes staff retention to be really high and results in clients getting passed around from one clinician to the next, cutting programs and groups.

review_title: Best place I've ever worked, enjoy going in everyday
job_title: Environmental Services Department in Rockford, IL
pros: Great coworkers, great benefits, purpose, all make for a rare work environment you enjoy being in every day. The company likes to promote from within so there's room for advancement. They value their people and show it by consistently hosting company events and giving back to the employees.
cons: Challenge of dealing with the client issues everyday makes it a tough job to do. The salary tends to be on the lower side but that's to be expected at a non-profit company

job_title: Mental Health Therapist in Rockford, IL
pros: Majority of the co-workers I had, which were many due to turnover, were amazing individuals and were probably the best co-workers I will ever have.  Seriously I still keep in touch with a handful of them and wish we could all work together again, just not at Rosecrance. Direct supervisors were always supportive.
cons: Pay is low, which is expected working at a community mental health facility; however, when the company has a for profit feel and the employees know that the CEO makes well over 6 figures is entirely too frustrating. This is especially true for employees who have standards that, although are achievable with working over 40+ hours or having a 90 plus client caseload, are too high for wanting a healthy work/life balance or providing exceptional client care.  Due to the lack of concern in regards to their employees work/life balance burnout happens frequently and quickly. Anyone who I worked with over two years there was burn out, and although the benefits in regards to PTO aren't horrible, the company does not create a culture that promotes a healthy balance. I had a former co-worker call the place a "factory" due to the heavy work load and expectations.

review_title: believe the company and CEO ratings - you probably don't want to work at Rosecrance, especially downstate Illinois
pros:
the mission of the organization, at least as stated, is laudable (charitable non-profit providing substance abuse and mental health treatment)
everyone on the staff in downstate Illinois was great
cons:
Profoundly dysfunctional, incompetent, abusive, soul-crushing management in Rockford that is driving the organization into the ground
low pay (it is a non-profit, after all, so that generally comes with the territory)

job_title: Substance Abuse Counselor in Rockford, IL
pros: Decent pay, consistent schedule, enjoyed the population I worked with
cons:
Management was belittling. Used scare tactics (e.g. you can be replaced easily). Policies(at times) were hindering not only to the clinician but also to clients. Advocating for clients behalf would not alter policies.  
Was forced to go to "listening sessions" every year where employees could voice their grievances.  This was a trick, because when you did voice a grievance, you were attacked or pulled into the big boss's office. You knew going to listening sessions, you were supposed to keep quiet.
Pay wasn't ideal, but they would supply you with ice cream on fridays?? I would give all the ice cream up in the world in order to be treated as a human being rather than an employee number.

pros: They occasionally have success treating adults for alcoholism and drug addiction.
cons: The management creates a toxic environment in a attempt to induce competition. The thinking is this behavior will make employees put out more noting aka billing etc... Roscrance has come to Champaign and absorbed most of the behavioral health businesses and other social non profits. After acquiring these companies they systematically push out 100% of the older staff members and replace them with company robots. Feel free to ask around, addict or employee will say they same thing. It is an evil company masking profit driven motives with a christian moral facade.

pros: Most of the Champaign people left over from Community Elements and Prairie Center were really nice.
cons: Very secretive and big brotherish company. CEO seems oblivious and the people waiting to take over for him are not much better. Upper management is out of touch and rude to employees and quite frankly don't care.

pros: Most employees are wonderful to work with, some campuses are amazing at helping clients.  Great training opportunities.
cons: Many changes to management and bosses get worse and downright incompetent at times. Supervision is absent. Boss comes in when he feels like it and gets a bruised ego whenever someone comes to him with possible solutions. The company adds responsibilities beyond education, experience, or proper training of employees.

pros: There are some good people to work with. They're few and in between but they're there nonetheless.
cons: No room for growth. Work expectations exceed compensation. Low compensation. No work/personal life balance. Entry level workers aren't heard at all by upper management. The blame game is very popular here. Promising PTO but always gets denied the day before, day of (very inconvenient), day after (yes I've been notified the denial the day after before) scheduled request.

pros: PTO, Work Experience , Good benefits
cons: Low pay, selfish management, very high overturn rate with staff, lack of staff, stressful work environment, 1 staff to 14 adolescents (sometimes more) with behavioral/emotional issues with different needs, no breaks for unit staff.

review_title: Rosecrance is a great place to learn and advance your career in substance abuse counseling
pros:
Regular opportunities for in-service and networking,
management help in career path,
lots of top down communication,
employee appreciation is strong, creative and refreshing
cons:
Management expects regular unpaid overtime,
emergency situations seem to be a regular thing

review_title: Not serious about recovery or life
pros: The unit specialists pour their hearts into trying to help the clients. With little to no training, there wasn't anything the unit specialists wouldn't do to try and save the clients life. It would be better if some of the upper management were recovering addicts as to better help the clients who are slipping through the cracks daily.
cons: Since the buyout from Rosecrance from the previous owners, the current director has absolutely no clue what the clients need, the unit specialist need, nor the counselors. It is pure chaos as the director only tries to impress the higher ups for Rosecrance. With little to no experience with actual addiction nor what it is like to be an addict, the director and the cohorts lack empathy and respect for the sanctity of human life. The director is always unavailable, has no interest in training future employees with such a serious issue as addiction. The clients are left alone majority of the time slipping through the cracks due to inadequate employee numbers because the turn over rate is extremely high at the champaign site. Employees are hired as cattle to fill spots instead of being cared for and trained with a heart and mind of how to save these peoples lives. If you care about your loved one, find a better place for their safety, recovery and a hopeful future. With addiction it is about getting rid of chaos not creating more for such a vulnerable human being who is learning how to live for the first time in their life.

pros: My initial overall impression was how great it was for the client to have so many options to help them with his/her recovery process (mainly in the Rockford area).  That is the "beast of Rosecrance" and both a pro and a con.  The direct line staff I interacted with appeared to be very committed to his/her clients and truly were invested in providing the best services possible.
cons:
Our existing company was bought out by Rosecrance which required much restructure, new titles, new everything.  I learned very quickly the executive management had no interest in being a team player, rather they operated similar to a dictatorship.  They created undue chaos despite being warned, begged, respectfully requested to slow a time line down to initiate new programming.  The whole experience quickly revealed the values and belief systems of the company.  Outwardly, they present much concern for the client.  Internally, our program was told, time and time again, to reschedule and cancel client's appointments to further the executive management's agenda.  Their agenda will override any and all client or employee's concerns.  This is important to know, not only from an employee perspective but also as a client.  Bottom line is:  the propaganda Rosecrance puts out about their values, etc. is NOT congruent with current employment relations and practices.  I guarantee you Rosecrance would not want an employee to talk to a "commercial client" (one who has private insurance $$$$$) like I have witnessed executive management talk to and treat his/her employees.  
It is less than professional to say the least.

review_title: Money means the most to Rosecrance, staff and patients come in distant 2nd
job_title: Unit Staff Detox in Rockford, IL
pros: Has pretty good insurance. And there is much to me learned from patients.
cons: Long hours and half the time no breaks (but you will always have to punch out or HR gets on you and will deduct the half hour pay anyway). Usually dangerously understaffed. High turn over (average employments for staff with direct contact with patients is about a year and a half). No communication from management, but when staff does not know of changes management is quick to blame staff for the error(changes in policies happen almost weekly). Disrespect and direct insults from management. Unit staff has no back up from management when it comes to patient behavioral issues, if the patient had insurance there will be NO repercussions no matter how well documented, unit staff has no authority to deal with inappropriate behaviors . Management/HR lies about raises (often promises 50 cent raise after 6 months and yearly.) Fact is at best you will only get a 33 cent raise yearly and thats if you are VERY well liked, most get much less. SOPs very much out of date. One was just "updated" this year saying that staff should wear gloves when changing diapers on the family unit, that unit has been gone for over 4 years. However management will be quick to ask you when you ask a question (that they usually don't know the answer to) "What does the SOP say?". The computer system is terrible and there is NO training on how to use it, it's all trial and error. Also the system goes down often with no other patient chart back ups for emergencies. Training in general is lacking, at best you get 2 or 3 days of training when about 2 weeks is required,

pros: There are plenty of opportunities for training and a culture that embraces ongoing learning and education. The work hours were okay.
cons: The rate of pay is low in comparison to jobs of its equal. For a company that treats substance abuse, there were zero testing done here post hire, but a need is present.

pros: Friendly staff, Nice working environment, Great benefits!
